options.(b): to have been born to a parent who at the time of the birth was a British citizen or settled in the United Kingdom or eligible territory

options.(a): Any court in the United Kingdom or eligible territory makes an order authorising the adoption of minor who is not a British citizen

text: Those requirements are that on the date on which the order is made or the convention adoption is effected

options.(a): The adopter or, in the case of a joint adoption, one of the adopters is a British citizen
options.(b): In a case within subsection (5)(b), the adopter or in the case of a joint adoption, both of the adopters are habitually resident in the United Kingdom or eligible territory

text: Where an order or convention adoption in consequence of which any person became a British citizen by virtue of subsection (5)
ceases to have effect, whether on annulment or otherwise, the cesser shall not affect the status of that person as a British citizen
If in the special circumstances of any particular case the Secretary of State thinks fit, he may for the purposes of subsection (4)
treat the person to whom the application relates as fulfilling the requirement specified in that subsection although, as regards any
one or more of the first ten years of that person’s life, the number of days on which he was absent from the United Kingdom in that year
or each of the years in question exceeds 90.
In this section and elsewhere in this Act settled has the meaning given by section 50
The relevant day for the purposes of subsection (1A) or (3A) is the day appointed for the commencement of section 42 of the Borders, Citizenship and Immigration Act 2009

text: A new-born infant who, after commencement is found abandoned in a British overseas territory shall,
unless the contrary is shown, be a deemed for the purposes of sebsection (1)-

options.(a): to have been born in that territory after commencement
options.(b): to have been born to a parent who at the time of the birth was a British overseas territories citizen or settled in

text: A person born in a British overseas territory after commencement who is not a British overseas territories citizen
by virtue of subsection (1) or (2) shall be entitled to be registered as such as a citizen if, while he is minor-

options.(a): his father or mother becomes such a citizen or becomes settled in a British overseas territory
options.(b): an application is made for his registration as such a citizen

text: A person born in a British overseas territory after commencement who is not a British overseas territories citizen
by virtue of subsection (1) or (2) shall be entitled, on an application for his registration as a British overseas territories citizen
made at any time after he has attained the age of ten years, to be registered as such a citizen if, as regards each of the first ten years
of that person’s life, the number of days on which he was absent from that territory in that year does not exceed 90.
Where after commencement an order authorising the adoption of a minor who is not a British overseas territories citizen
is made by a court in any British overseas territory, he shall be a British overseas territories citizen as from the date
on which the order is made if the adopter or, in the case of a joint adoption, one of the adopters, is a British overseas territories citizen on that date.
Where-

options.(a): a minor who is not a British overseas territories citizen is adopted under a convention adoption
options.(b): on the date which the adoption is effected-
options.(b-i): the adopter or, in the case of a joint adoption, one of the adopters is a British overseas territories citizen
options.(b-ii): the adopter or, in the case of a joint adoption, both of the adopters are habitually resident in a designated territory
options.(c): the convention adoption is effected under the law of a contry or territory outside the designated territory

text: Where an order or a Convention adoption in consequence of which any person became a
British overseas territories citizen by virtue of subsection (5) ceases to have effect,
whether on annulment or otherwise, the cesser shall not affect the status of that person as such a citizen.
if in the special circumstances of any particular case the Secretary of State thinks fit,
he may for the purposes of subsection (4) treat the person to whom the application relates as
fulfilling the requirements specified in that subsection although, as regards any one or
more of the first ten years of that person’s life, the number of days on which he was absent from the
British overseas territory there mentioned in that year or each of the years in question exceeds 90.
